content.description: A bar magnet is brought near five different objects, <math alttext="A through E" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">‐</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math>, to determine the magnetic behavior of each object. The bar magnet picks up objects <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, and <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math>. The bar magnet does not pick up objects <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> or <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></math>.
content.question: A student makes the observation that when Object <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math> is brought near Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is attracted to Object <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math>. The student claims that either one of objects <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> and <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math> must be a magnet. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> was attracted to Object <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math>.
Yes, because Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> was attracted to the bar magnet.

No, because objects <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> were both attracted to the bar magnet.
No, because Object <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math> was attracted to the bar magnet.

content.answer: Yes, because Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> was attracted to Object <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></math>.
